title.narrative: 002 DISPLACEMENT AND EQUITABLE ACCESS TO QUALITY EDUCATION

description.narrative: 'By 2020, increased numbers of pastoralist and displaced children participate in quality primary education services, which contributes to Access To Justice, Child Protection â€“ Strengthen Families And Communities, Equitable Access To Quality Education, Equitable Access To Quality Education (Covid), Equity â€“ Focus On Girls' And Inclusive Education, Learning And Child-Friendly Schools, Learning Outcomes. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Evaluations, Research And Data, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2020, equitable access created and quality education and training provided to all learners at pre-primary and primary level and girls' access to secondary education increased, with a focus on the most disadvantaged and vulnerable children, populations and localities

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: 'By 2020, increased numbers of pastoralist and displaced children participate in quality primary education services

description.narrative: UNICEF partnered with government and humanitarian partners at all levels to enhance access to education services from pre-primary to secondary education for 3,944,807 (1,802,624 from pastoralist communities, 355,692 internally displaced, 204,766 refugee) through community mobilization, provision of education supplies, training and recruitment of teachers and facilitators, construction and rehabilitation of classrooms. After closure of schools due to COVID-19, UNICEF supported 5.2 million primary and secondary school children (46% girls) to access distance learning. Government and coordination systems were strengthened through staff recruitment, formalizing relationships between different stakeholders, evaluations to inform development of guidelines to support effective education service delivery. | Status:Partially met | As-of Date:24/08/2020
